description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: A general curfew will apply in Georgia from Tuesday (31 March) at 08:00 a.m. (local time). Persons are only allowed to leave their apartments for necessary purchases. In addition, there is an absolute night-time curfew between 09:00 p.m. and 06:00 a.m., which also applies countrywide. Public gatherings of more than three people and public transport are also to be suspended, with the exception of taxis.

description: On March 23 the Health Minister of Georgia has announced starting of rapid diagnostic testing from Wednesday, March 25. On April 1The Ministry of Health has expanded a list of testing criteria for the novel coronavirus, which will now include symptomatic patients (with high fever), and high-risk groups such as frontline medical personnel. UPDATE: The Ministry of Health has expanded a list of testing criteria for the novel coronavirus, which will now include symptomatic patients (with high fever), and high-risk groups such as frontline medical personnel. The decision has been voiced by Tamar Gabunia, Deputy Health Minister, at a government task force briefing to update on the coronavirus outbreak in Georgia. Prior to the change, the COVID-19 testing algorithm only included suspected patients with travel history of coronavirus-affected countries, and people who had come into contact with patients already diagnosed with the disease
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 23 the Health Minister of Georgia has announced starting of rapid diagnostic testing from Wednesday, March 25. On April 1The Ministry of Health has expanded a list of testing criteria for the novel coronavirus, which will now include symptomatic patients (with high fever), and high-risk groups such as frontline medical personnel. On April 29 the Health Ministry expanded testing for for vulnerable, highrisk
groups. UPDATE: The original policy that was announced on March 23 was expanded. Initially, the testing included suspected patients with travel
history in countries hit hard by the novel coronavirus, people who
had come into contact with patients already diagnosed with the
disease, symptomatic patients (with high fever), and high-risk
groups such as frontline medical personnel. Now the list is being expanded for vulnerable, highrisk groups

description:
On April 13 The Georgian government has quarantined Khidiskuri village, part
of Khashuri municipality in Shida Kartli region (situated to the
northwest of Tbilisi), as two cases of COVID-19 have been
confirmed in the village. In addition to restrictions enacted by the
state of emergency decree, following regulations will come into
force in Khidiskuri:
entering and leaving the village will be banned;
Police force of the Ministry of Internal Affairs will ensure the
implementation and observance of quarantine restrictions;
Village residents can only leave their homes in case of
emergency;
Locals will be allowed to carry out farmwork in accordance
with the recommendations issued by the Ministry of Health;
Among the media outlets, only journalists of the Georgian
Public Broadcaster will be permitted to operate in the village.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 23 the Government of Georgia has announced, that the supply and sale of all goods and products shall be suspended for the duration of the state of emergency. On April 2 added types of economic activities authorized under the state of emergency regulations which are effective until April 21. Oil and gas production companies, as well as businesses adopting remote work model will now be permitted to resume operations. UPDATE: On April 2 the Georgian government has amended a decree issued on March 23 adding types of economic activities authorized under the state of emergency regulations which are effective until April 21. Oil and gas production companies, as well as businesses adopting remote work model will now be permitted to resume operations.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 15 State Representative of Imereti region in western Georgia stated that 13 cemeteries in Kutaisi and three cemeteries in Zestaponi municipality will be closed during the Easter celebrations. Shalamberidze could not yet specify the date of closure, but he said the cemeteries will be supposedly closed for three days to avoid large public gatherings amid the coronavirus.

description: On March 23 the Government of Georgia announced, that it shall be prohibited to hold all types of cultural events, both indoors and outdoors, including concerts, performances, temporary and permanent exhibitions, rehearsals, tours, master classes, trainings and conferences, with the exception of remote form.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 23 the Government of Georgia has announced, that Assemblies and/or demonstrations under the Law of Georgia on Assemblies and Demonstrations shall be prohibited for the
duration of the state of emergency.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On March 23 the Government of Georgia has announced that any assembly of more than 10 natural persons in a public space shall be prohibited.For the purposes of this article, a public
space shall mean any indoor or outdoor area, unless it is a space used by individuals for residential purposes.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 23 the Government of Georgia announced, that all types of training, conferences, seminars, except for the remote form, shall be prohibited.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 28 State Representative of Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region (Georgia) Alexandre Motserelia has announced about prohibiting travel of more than three people per car
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Georgia banned gatherings of more than three people, except groceries and farmacies, where a distance of two meters is mandatory.

In Georgia, it is only allowed to travel in light vehicles (including taxis), taking into consideration the recommendations of the Ministry of Health, with a maximum of three people (including the driver), with the passengers seated in the back of the car, as of March 31st, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
